title: 113_hr1422
content: The Act may be cited as the "EPA Science Advisory Board Reform Act of 2014". The Environmental Research, Development, and Demonstration Authorization Act of 1978 is amended to ensure the independence of the Advisory Board and specify membership requirements, including qualifications related to scientific and technical expertise. The Board's membership must be balanced, with at least ten percent from government entities, and individuals with relevant expertise should not be excluded due to affiliations. Board members with interests in specific parties cannot participate in related activities. The Board's membership must be balanced, with at least ten percent from government entities. Board members cannot participate in activities involving the review of their own work or be federally registered lobbyists. The Administrator solicits public nominations for the Board from various federal agencies and accepts public comments on nominees. Upon provisional nomination, nominees must disclose financial relationships, including EPA grants, contracts, and relevant professional activities for the past five years. Disclosure of professional activities includes representational work, expert testimony, and contract work, with identification of the party involved. Reports are made public, excluding specific dollar amounts, for each Board member upon selection. The Agency must make conflict of interest waivers and recusal agreements public for Board members. Board members serve staggered three-year terms with a limit of two terms over ten years. Amendments are made to the record-keeping section of the Act. Amendments are made to the record-keeping section of the Act regarding the submission of draft risk or hazard assessments to the Board for review. Amendments to the record-keeping section of the Act require draft risk or hazard assessments to be submitted to the Board for review. Member committees and investigative panels must operate according to specific provisions and do not have decision-making authority for the Board. They are also prohibited from reporting directly to the Environmental Protection Agency. The Environmental Protection Agency is amending Section 8 of the Act to enhance public participation in advisory activities. The Administrator and the Board must make reports and scientific information public, hold information-gathering sessions before major activities, and address public comments before convening committees or seeking advice from the Board. The Board and investigative panels must consider public comments on questions asked, without narrowing the scope of advisory activities. Public comments, including oral comments, shall not be time-restricted, and the public has 15 days after meetings to provide additional comments for the Board's consideration. The Board's advisory activities should avoid making policy recommendations and clearly communicate uncertainties. They should ensure advice reflects members' views, conduct periodic reviews, and be responsive to Congress. The Act does not replace the requirements of the Federal Advisory Committee Act or the Ethics in Government Act of 1978.
